Deep pockets and free money cause it all to last longer, but Tesla has serious issues. The cars have too many accidents, with too much damage and catch fire too easily. As result insurers will multiply coverage fees (a major Dutch one changed the fee from 750 to 5000 a year). Next to that there are the production issues with the new model. And I cannot imagine the cheaper model has less issues than the more expensive one. So, no, not before 2018, probably not even before 2019, but in 2018 it will become widely known Tesla is just not good enough technically and that is basically end of story.

Tesla is rated B- by S&P. Historically default risk for company rated B has been c.4.5% over next year, although much lower over last decade c.2.5% for 2006-2015 even taking into account spike in 2009. Tesla at the weak end of B range. Risk jumps markedly if drops to CCC or lower (c.24%), although many of these companies will be in terrible condition (almost by definition).

Estimated cash burn in Q4 was $1bn.  Cash flow (earnings before interest and taxes) in 2017 will be a negative $600 million on revenues of $10.5 billion.  However, depreciation and amortization are noncash charges, and those items will add back $1 billion, so 2017 EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) should be a positive $400 million.  Including capital expenditures, cash reserves on the balance sheet will fall from $2.2 billion at the end of 2016 to $900 million by the end of 2017.  This sets up another capital raise, which will be dilutive, but there is no indication that Tesla won't be able to access capital markets in 2017, and it has a sizable asset-based credit line secured by its finished goods inventory.

Tesla's Z-score is 6% (https://www.macroaxis.com/invest/ratio/TSLA--Probability_Of_Bankruptcy). As this is the probability for bankruptcy in the next 2 years, I multiply the Z-score by (2-1-1.5/12) to arrive at a (first & rough) default probability for 2017.

Tesla is 13 years old (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tesla,_Inc.), during which time is has not filed for Bankruptcy (despite being extremely close to doing so in late 2008). The leadership which lead it through that turmoil is still in charge (most notably, Elon Musk). That indicates to me that a weak prior on Tesla defaulting this year is less than 1/13, and the inside view (TSLA is in much better shape than it has been throughout much of its history) suggests that it is slightly less than that.
